div1.p: THE WASHINGTON POST, THURSDAY, APRIL 18, 1901.
YELLOW FEVER GERMS

Gen. Sternberg Positive Mos-
quitoes Spread Them.
DEMONSTRATED BY EXPERIMENT

His Interesting Statement Before American
Social Science Association--Tests Made in
Havana Described--Transmission of Dread
Disease by Contagion Declared Impos-
sible--Says the Germ of the Disease Has
Not Been Discovered with Microscope.

The sessions of the annual convention
of the American Social Science Associ-
ation were continued yesterday at Colum-
bian University, with largely increased
audiences. Several papers of interest were
read and discussed. “Health” was the
general subject, and it was treated in its
widely diversified branches. Nutrition,
factory hygiene, health fads, and the so-
cial effect of insanitation in dwellings
were the subjects of the morning discus-
sions and papers.

“Transmission of Yellow Fever by the
Mosquito,” the subject of an address by
Surgeon General George M. Sternberg, U.
S. A., which opened the evening session,
proved the most interesting of the day.
Gen. Sternberg recited a series of experi-
ments made by army surgeons in Cuba
within the past year, which, by a process
of elimination, as well as by direct re-
sults, he regarded as establishing conclu-
sively that the yellow fever germ infects
the blood; that it may be transmitted by
infusion, or by the bite of a particular
species of mosquito after the insect has
filled itself with the blood of a person
suffering from yellow fever.

A feature of the conclusions drawn by
the surgeon general was that the fumiga-
tion of clothing, bedding, &c., which has
been exposed to supposed contagion by
contact with infected persons, is abso-
lutely valueless, unnecessary, and with-
out any scientific basis.

Considerable discussion of yellow fever
took place at the conclusion of Gen.
Sternberg's address, but his statements
as to transmission of yellow fever by mos-
quito bite was not challenged. The talk
was directed entirely to correlative is-
sues.

The evening session was opened by
President Kingsbury, who announced that
the association was extremely gratified
by the large attendance at its meetings,
and had decided to hold its annual con-
vention here next year in the early
spring. This announcement was greeted
with applause. President Kingsbury then
introduced Gen. Sternberg, who spoke
extempore, and excused himself for not
having a paper prepared.
History of Yellow Fever.

Gen. Sternberg first reviewed the his-
tory and described the characteristics of
yellow fever. Several theories as to its
original transplanting to the West Indies
existed, he said--one that it was brought
from Africa by slave ships. Havana, he
said, had suffered a severe epidemic of
the disease in the early history of the city,
and then for more than a hundred years
had been entirely free from the disease.
Rio de Janeiro never knew yellow fever
until 1848, when it was carried to the
Brazilian city by an infected vessel from
Havana. From this, Gen. Sternberg ar-
gued that yellow fever does not originate
from climatic conditions, and in support of
this view recalled that for years there
was annually an epidemic of the disease
in New Orleans, so that the people be-
lieved that it was a necessary concomi-
tant of warm weather. For many years
past, Gen. Sternberg said, there had been
no yellow fever in New Orleans of an
epidemic character.

He also stated that at Vera Cruz, Mex-
ico, yellow fever is epidemic every year,
as it is at Rio de Janeiro. Persons from
the City of Mexico go to Vera Cruz, con-
tract the disease, return and often die of
it in Mexico City, but no one there had
ever been known to catch it from a dis-
eased person, and it never occurs there.
This was likewise true of Pedropolis, a
suburb of Rio de Janeiro, which, like the
City of Mexico, is at a considerable eleva-
tion above the sea level.
Not Caused by Climatic Conditions.

Other features of the disease, as de-
scribed by Gen. Sternberg, were the need
of an elevated temperature and of mois-
ture for its development. Its develop-
ment, he said, depends upon climatic con-
ditions, but is not caused by them. In
general, he asserted, it is known that
every outbreak of the disease can be
traced to the arrival of infected persons
in the community in which it occurs. It
is carried by ships from infected ports,
and when it breaks out in a city travels
from block to block and through channels
that are directly in contact with the in-
fected area. High stone walls about build-
ings, Gen. Sternberg said, are known to
operate as a preventive. Gen. Sternberg
then briefly described his own investiga-
tions of yellow fever in the West Indies
and South and Central America, covering
a number of years.

The specific cause of yellow fever, he
said, has not yet been demonstrated,
though many physicians have believed
that they had found it. Dr. Sanarelli, he
said, had studied the disease in Brazil,
found what he thought was the germ,
and received a prize offered by the gov-
ernment of that country of $10,000 as a
result of his investigations. In the light
of recent investigation Gen. Sternberg
stated that he was compelled to assert
his belief that Sanarelli's germs were not
the yellow fever bacteria.

Proceeding to the main subject of his
lecture, Gen. Sternberg stated that it had
been definitely proven that malarial fever
is transmitted by mosquitoes. The germ
of that disease has been identified by
miscroscopy, he said, and had been found
in the blood of a healthy person after he
had been bitten by a mosquito which had
been permitted to feed upon the blood of
a person suffering from the disease.
Transmission by Mosquitoes.

Dr. Finleay, of Havana, said Gen. Stern-
berg, was the first to suggest, some fifteen
years ago, that yellow fever was trans-
mitted by mosquitoes. Dr. Finley's exper-
iments had been by no means confirma-
tory of this theory, however. The profes-
sion did not accept his view, and it gained
no supporters until last year, when a
board of yellow fever experts had been
sent to Cuba under the direction of the
Surgeon General's office to investigate
this theory of transmission. The first ex-
periments were made by Drs. Reed, Jesse
✗ H. Lazear, and Carroll. They first isolat-
ed themselves for a longer period than
that of incubation of yellow fever--three
to five days--and then inoculated them-
selves by permitting mosquitoes which
had filled themselves with the blood of in-
fected persons, to bite them. Dr. Reed
and Dr. Carroll developed yellow fever,
but Dr. Lazear did not.

✗ The latter then entered a dead house,
where were the bodies of persons who
had died of yellow fever. While there he
observed a mosquito upon his hand, and
thinking he would surely become inoculat-
ed if he permitted the insect to bite him,
he did so, developed the disease, and died.

✗ “He fell a martyr to his zeal for his
profession,” said Gen. Sternberg. The
others--Carroll and Reed--had severe at-
tacks of the disease, but recovered.

Satisfied that they were upon the right
track, these physicians then made elabo-
rate preparations for an extended experi-
ment. Gov. Gen. Wood supplied the funds
from the revenues of the island as a mat-
ter of vital interest to its inhabitants, and
an experiment station was erected at a
sufficient distance from Havana to insure
the subjects of the experiment from con-
tagion by other means than that pro-
posed. Volunteers were secured from the
army and from the ranks of newly ar-
rived emigrants from Spain, who took the
view that they would surely have yellow
fever anyhow in Cuba, and that it would
be better to have it where they would be
well cared for and receive a considerable
money bonus, as each of the volunteers
for this experiment did receive.
Positive Results by Experiment.

The result of the experiments was en-
tirely satisfactory, said Gen. Sternberg,
and extremely positive. The scores of
people at the experiment station were kept
isolated there for several days over the
extreme incubation period of yellow fever,
and were then inoculated by the bite of
mosquitoes which had been infected as in
the other cases. Over 80 per cent. of the
volunteers had real yellow fever. For-
tunately none died. Gen. Sternberg said,
in this connection, that Dr. Reed's experi-
ments were successful and Dr. Finley's
unsuccessful, because the former took the
mosquito just after it had fed on the blood
of an infected person and permitted it to
bite a person not infected. There was no
inoculation resultant. Dr. Reed had kept
the infected mosquitoes for twelve or four-
teen days after they had bitten the per-
sons suffering from the disease, and dis-
covered that this was necessary to obtain
positive results. He believed that the
germs multiplied in the mosquito's body
and found their way into all its parts, in-
cluding the salivary glands, through which
they distributed the infection. From the
experiments in the transmission of ma-
laria by mosquitoes, Dr. Reed took his
cue about keeping the infected mosquitoes.

It was determined furthermore, said
Gen. Sternberg, that the bite of a newly
infected mosquito neither causes infection
nor makes the person bitten immune, as
was supposed by some. This discovery
about the germs requiring time to de-
velop in the body of the mosquito, he
said, cleared up the mystery about the
spread of the disease in cities where it
had been studied, and where it was found
that secondary cases did not occur until
fifteen or twenty days after the initial
cases arrived.

In summarizing the result of Dr. Reed's
experimenting, Gen. Sternberg stated that
it had been positively determined that
the mosquito known as the culex fascia-
tus distributes the disease, as stated, and
that it is not transmitted by the species
of mosquito which is found at greater
altitudes. It had also been found that
a minute quantity of blood drawn from a
person suffering from yellow fever and
injected into the blood of a healthy per-
son would give the latter the disease.

The yellow fever germ itself, he declar-
ed, had not been discovered, and it is be-
lieved to be ultramicroscopical, as in the
case of the germ of the foot and mouth
disease, which can be separated by a
mechanical process, but gives negative re-
sults under the microscope.
No Transmission by Contagion.

Perhaps the most interesting portion of
Gen. Sternberg's address covered the sub-
ject of other forms of contagion. He con-
tended that there are none, and asserted
positively that the yellow fever germ can
be transmitted only by direct introduction
into the blood. He stated that a new set
of volunteers submitted to a second test
at the Cuban experiment station, after
those inoculated by mosquito bite had
been discharged. The second volunteers
put on clothing taken from persons suf-
fering from yellow fever, slept in bed-
clothes which had just been taken from
the cots of victims, sick and dead, and
made every effort, under direction of the
attendant physicians, to acquire yellow
fever by contagion from such clothing and
garments. These efforts, said Gen. Stern-
berg, were wholly without success. Not
a single one of the volunteers was made
even unwell by days of close contact with
clothing which would have been declared
fit only to be burned under the old views
as to this means of disseminating the
dread disease.

Gen. Sternberg then read extracts from
an order of the War Department covering
the extermination of mosquitoes and their
exclusion from dwellings in lands subject
to yellow fever. At the close of the paper
questions were asked regarding the al-
leged protection afforded by high walls
against the progress of yellow fever epi-
demics. The surgeon general explained
that the mosquito which carries the yel-
low fever germ flies low, and this fact
about insect pests was corroborated by
the experience of President Kingsbury.

The session concluded with the reading
by Secretary Rcot of an abstract of a pa-
per on “Food as the Principal Factor in
the Cause of Disease,” of which Dr. El-
mer Lee, of New York, was the author.
Dr. Lee declared the swallowing of food
without proper mastication and satura-
tion with saliva a fruitful scource of dis-
ease, and called food so taken into the
system raw, saying that it is poisonous.

Proper, natural swallowing of food is
unconscious, he said, and to swallow food
before it ceases to have taste and zest
and slips naturally down the throat is to
expose the system to the action of in-
jurious elements, which may lead to dis-
ease at any time.

Announcement of the programme for to-
day was coupled with a renewal of the
invitation of the association to the public
to attend.
Factory Sanitation and Health Fads.

The morning session was devoted to the
discussion of questions of hygiene, this
department being under Dr. W. H. Daly,
chairman, and Dr. Elmer Lee, secretary.
A large majority of those in attendance
were women, who seemed to take great
interest in the papers read. The first was
by John H. Patterson, of Dayton, Ohio,
who described the large manufacturing
establishment of which he is the head. He
said that it had been found to the pe-
cuniary benefit of that institution to pro-
vide for the comfort, sanitary surround-
ings, and agreeable environment of the
employes while at work. He described the
buildings and their close adherence to the
principles of hygiene and artistic effect.
“We have demonstrated,” said Mr. Pat-
terson, “that this system pays the em-
ploye, the manufacturer, and the buyer
in the health of one, the profit of the
second, and the improved quality of
the product purchased by the third.”

Dr. Grace Peckham Murray, of New
York, read a paper on “Health Fads of
To-day.” She said they were number-
less, and declared that charlatans had
taken advantage of the general feeling
that health is of the greatest importance.
Christian Science and osteopathy were ar-
raigned severely by the lecturer, who de-
clared that they should be subjected to
the same close and direct supervision as
other methods of healing. She declared
that the spread of pestilential diseases
in large cities was most often due to
quacks, who claim that there can be no
contamination by association with a dis-
eased person, and conceal the character
of the cases they are “treating.”

Dr. C. W. Chancellor, of Washington,
D. C., described “Social Evils Resulting
from Unsanitary Dwellings.” Dr. Chan-
cellor declared that 33 per cent. of the
deaths among the poor were due to the
absence of sanitary arrangements in their
places of abode, and particularly in the
failure to provide for pure air. He de-
clared that one out of four infants born
to parents of the tenements and squaled
lodging places dies within a year, and at-
tributed this mortality to lack of sanita-
tion. In the opinion of the lecturer it
should be impossible, under the law, for
owners to maintain unsanitary dwellings
for the occupation of human beings, and
that in the event of their failure to make
their properties suitable for healthful
habitation, the law should permit and de-
mand the destruction of such dwellings.

Dr. Irving C. Rosse, of Washington, D.
C., who was to have read a paper on the
general relation of social to sanitary con-
ditions, was absent.
